content: Finish this sentence " I knew I was raising a (insert your kid's mil title here)when...." For example and my personal experience: I knew I was raising Marines when ...they turned EVERYTHING into weapons. Empty paper towel rolls, un-cooked spaghetti noodles, cattails (the vegetation, not the cat) and even pb&j sandwiches (bitten into shape) ...their favorite toy in the garage was the GUN POWDER (which was supposed to be for re-loading - NOT for fire-starting!!!)YIKES!!!"Where the heck are your eyebrows, Fearless???" ...they made wooden broad swords longer than they were tall and proceeded to WHACK on one another on the GARAGE ROOF ...one of them broke the same arm TWICE! "Mom, my arm feels funny..." and the other kept a pair of crutches "just in case" ...and finally after we watched a demonstration of DI's from Parris Island putting a recruit through... ah-HEM, his paces, my kid looks at me with a big grin on his face and said "Isn't it COOL???". Not the word I was thinking of....

content: Ya know you're a military family when you combat park the vehicles in the garage. Ya know you're a military family when the wife's name is on the driver side windshield of the urban assualt vehicle(family van). Ya know you're a military family if you use concertia wire to landscape the yard(sandbags will work too). Ya know you're a military family if your daughter needs a DA31 approved by the CO(Dad) AND the 1SG(Mom)two weeks in advance before going on a date. Ya know you're a military family when said date must stand uniform and vehicle inspection before said date.

content: "I knew I was raising a Marine...." I guess the first clue was when camo started being his fashion of choice. In reality, I guess it was more evident when he joined his high school's Marine Corps JROTC and really took it serious...all four years of school. He left for Parris Island nine days after his high school graduation. Don

content: quote: Originally posted by DeBe888: Finish this sentence " I knew I was raising a (insert your kid's mil title here)when...." I knew I was raising a soldier when, at 4 years old, Richard was absolutely fascinated with my freshly-shined boots. I'd spend forever spit shining them to a mirror finish, and as soon as I put them next to the wall in my bedroom where they went, he'd hop in them and traipse all around the house scuffing them up. It was frustrating, but cute. I wear an 11 1/2, and his feet were no bigger than my hands. One day, he asks me, "Daddy, where do you go all those times?" He was referencing deployments, of course, as we spend about 7 to 8 months in the field in the Infantry (not all at once). So I explained to him that we go to train, kind of like camping. He looks at me quizzically for a minute and says, "But, if you don't live in houses, how do you go to the bathroom?" (Keep in mind, he'd just turned 4). I said, "Well, son, we go in the woods. It's like being in the back yard, and you have to go so bad, you find a tree and just... go." That's not a very wise thing to say to a 4-year old. So I knew I was raising a soldier when he'd be outside playing, stop, flap his boyhood in the wind, and urinate on the one tree we had in the yard saying, "I'm like daddy! I'm in the Army! We pee on trees!" Ah, memories. Richard, now 21, is in the Air Force (if his mother didn't scare him away from it - I don't know, as we haven't even spoken in 7 years or so). It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: LOL 21! Yep, we saw a fair amount of camo at my house too. He would trapse around in his dad's old bdu's when he was about 11 and they were hanging off him. I guess I should have gotten a clue when all Christmas and Birthday gifts required a trip to the Army surplus store! My youngest was ROTC for all four years too. Got Outstanding Cadet at Summer Leadership School. Not that I'm proud of him or anything..... Follow - Boot schlepping and peeing outside! Geez, I can sooo relate to that.....

content: I ran across an old photo while I was packing to come overseas - unfortunately, it's in storage, or I'd post it here. It's my older son when he was about 4: wearing my Class A blouse and my Dad's green beret (he was SF). That was a pretty serious clue, doncha think? That same little boy - now in his mid-30s - was selected for E-8 and frocked as a 1SG prior to DEROSing from Europe today to take his new job in CA. HIS little boy - age 8 - has a full set of ACUs that he wears whenever possible. Of course, now HIS rank and stuff need to be updated, too. He even has his own screen name for email: SFCjrXXXX@XXXX.com - and I guess he'll have to update that, too. I'm just waiting for one of my grandDAUGHTERS to hit the Long Grey Line or another Army entry point. Then my life will be complete.

content: All three of my children, 2 sons and a daughter had ROTC 3 or more years in HS. Their choice, absolutely no pressure from me. Oldest Son joined the US Army 1996-2004 & 2008- present. (he made the 5th Generation Army direct paternal line.) Youngest son joined US Marines 2006-present. I knew since they were born, there was a possibility all three would join. Two of the three did.
